2.1 – Ancient Beliefs That Shaped Israel

Before Christ, Israel lived among nations rich in myth, symbolism, and worship of the heavens. Mesopotamia spoke of the Tree of Life and divine councils. Egypt carried stories of gods descending, ruling, and resurrecting. Canaan told of Baal, the storm-god, and Asherah, the so-called “queen of heaven.”

Israel, chosen to be distinct, was constantly tempted to blend these beliefs into their own worship. The prophets cried against this fusion, yet fragments of these ancient myths still echo in the Scriptures. Jeremiah 44 speaks of the people burning incense to the “queen of heaven,” a title predating Israel’s monotheistic faith.

2.2 – The Books That Were Removed

Not all of Israel’s writings survived into the canon we hold today. Some were suppressed, others forgotten, yet they whisper of a larger story:

  • 1 Enoch – visions of angels descending, teaching mankind secrets, and the prophecy of a coming Son of Man.
  • Jubilees – a retelling of Genesis with angelic involvement, cosmic calendars, and deeper layers of covenant.
  • The Book of Jasher – referenced in Joshua and 2 Samuel, now largely lost.

These books reveal a faith more mystical, cosmic, and apocalyptic than the later political structures allowed.

2.3 – The Memory of Eden in Ancient Texts

The idea of a lost paradise—the garden of God—was not unique to Genesis. Mesopotamian myths spoke of a place where the gods walked with men, guarded by cherub-like beings. Ezekiel 28 and 31 recall the “trees of Eden,” comparing the pride of kings to those exalted in that ancient garden.

The Eden memory became more than history—it was a symbol of what humanity had lost and what only God’s Kingdom could restore.

2.4 – The True Kingdom vs. Political Zion

From the earliest days, a tension emerged: was Israel to be a holy nation under God’s reign, or a political state like the kingdoms of men?

When kings arose, Zion became more than a hill—it became a symbol of political power. Prophets warned that the true Kingdom was not about stone walls or armies, but about righteousness and justice.

The collision of heavenly Zion and political Zion would become one of the deepest struggles leading up to the time of Christ.

2.5 – Messianic Hopes Before Christ

Even before Christ, the people whispered of a Deliverer. The Dead Sea Scrolls reveal communities expecting a Messiah, sometimes even two: one priestly, one kingly. Daniel foresaw a “Son of Man” coming with clouds. Isaiah spoke of a Servant who would suffer and yet triumph.

These hopes were not uniform, but they all pointed to a longing—for the restoration of Eden, for the defeat of corrupt powers, and for the rise of the true Kingdom of God.

2.6 – Closing Reflection

Ancient beliefs, removed books, and prophetic tensions all converge into a single truth: humanity yearned for a Kingdom not made with hands. Yet between the whispers of Eden and the shadow of Zion, a deeper mystery was unfolding.
